column1:
AP Brad Friesen Fort McMurray-Wood Buffalo

Meet Brad:

A third-generation Albertan and a proud community member for 22 years
column2:
Brad Friesen understands the challenges and opportunities faced by people in Fort McMurray-Wood Buffalo because he’s lived those challenges and opportunities.

Currently employed in the oil sands
column3: Brad is a former small business owner
column4: a dedicated community volunteer and comes from a long line of farmers and family members committed to sustainability
column5:
serving others and building community.

Brad’s mother was a nurse
column7: paramedics and health care service providers among his relatives
column8:
giving him an understanding of the current issues faced in our health care system – by people and by health care workers.

Educated at what is now Olds College of Agriculture and Technology
column9:
Brad was also working towards a degree in education before being called back to help out on the family farm.

While that led Brad back to his roots
column10:
it was also the beginning of a journey that guided him to the community through the eventual operations of Dunvegan Gardens in Draper. Brad’s experience leading Dunvegan Gardens furthered his resolve as a strong advocate for small and local business and in standing up for common sense ideas.

Brad has supported or served with many community organizations in his over two decades here
column11: including the Wood Buffalo Food Bank
column17:
school groups and Scouts Canada.

column1:
AP Barry Morishita Brooks-Medicine Hat

About Barry

Barry Morishita is a born-and-raised Albertan and has lived in Brooks since 1989. He is a husband
column3:
and grandfather.

A proud 3rd generation Japanese Canadian
column4: Barry’s paternal great-grandparents’ immigrated to Canada in 1913. They
column6: spent several years confined to a World War 2 Japanese internment camp in Tashme
column8: during which time his father was born. Once released
column9:
they chose to move to Alberta in 1947 and eventually settled in the Rosemary area. His mother immigrated from England in 1958.

Barry first became involved in his community as both a member and chair of the Parks and Recreation Committee in the city of Brooks. The committee’s work on the city’s first-ever master plan led to a regional arena
column11:
and a library that all continue to be a source of pride and ongoing development in the community.

column1:
AP Jenny Yeremiy Calgary-North West

Meet Jenny:

Jennifer is a Geophysicist with 22 years of experience working in the energy sector including influencing policies and regulations related to clean up of oil and gas sites for the last two years. Jennifer has expressed: "I am frustrated with our current government policies and inactions and do not feel represented. I understand policies must address the needs of all Albertans
column3: and I believe government representatives need to be accountable to their constituents." Jennifer has a mix of knowledge
column5:
experience and heart to represent our area of Calgary well.

She and her family have also been actively involved in the West Springs-Cougar Ridge Community Association
column6: including the planting of 1500 trees and seedlings
column7:
as well as in the Hockey Calgary community.

To share some of her commitments Jenny has summarized much of the Alberta Party 2023 election platform in this document.

Campaigns are a lot of work
column9: we can send Jennifer to the Alberta Legislature. You can help us accomplish this by either hosting a barbeque or coffee party for Jennifer to meet some of your friends or neighbours
column11:
lit drops or making phone calls.

Join our team
column12:
and help us win this.

column1:
AP Lynn Lekisch Central Peace-Notley

Meet Lynn:

Lynn Lekisch resides on the farm that she grew up on in Central Peace-Notley
column2:
and is running because our constituents need encouragement that their Alberta Party MLA will be an accountable voice in Legislature.

Lynn’s grandfather and his family immigrated from Austria following WW2 in order to escape cultural persecution and was one of the first community doctors in Valleyview and in Clear Hills County. Lynn’s mother was born and raised in the area
column3:
as were her Cree and Beaver ancestors.

Central Peace-Notley needs a candidate for MLA who knows the communities and roads (and even the places where there are no roads) extending from Bear Canyon to Fox Creek and Jean Cote to Bay Tree.

Lynn Lekisch is an Environmental Scientist
column5:
and a Certified Engineering Technologist with a specialty in soil and water.

As a First Nations woman with experience in health care
column10:
Lynn Lekisch has developed a broad perspective of the issues facing our Province from hands-on engagement.

Lynn Lekisch is the only prospective candidate who lives in Central Peace-Notley
column11: that can best represent the urban
column13: First Nations and Métis constituents of Central Peace-Notley and will be the advocate for better health care
column16:
and government accountability while tackling the short-term and long-term cost of living increases.

We need to work together to ensure the candidate for MLA will work to address what matters most to you.

column1:
AP Sue Timanson Sherwood Park

Meet Sue:


Sue's a daughter
column3: Mum and Nana. She grew up in Westboro
column5:
married Kent and they raised their family (Courtney & Spencer) in Sherwood Park.

She's been deeply embedded in our community even before her Mum (Carole Eastaugh) was the Executive Director of the Sherwood Park & DIstrict Chamber of Commerce in the 1990's.Sueplayed ringette and hockey
column6:
and continues to play and coach women's soccer in Sherwood Park.

Active in local and provincial PC politics until 2017 when she found the Alberta Party whose values better align with her beliefs and principles.

Sueis excited to represent the Alberta Party again for the 2023 election and hopes to build on the support we built in 2019.

She brings strong
column8: forward-thinking leadership and will be a positive and responsive MLA.Suebelieves it's time to walk the walk in putting people over politics
column9:
that together we can find ways to see past ideology and build common sense solutions to issues facing Albertans both provincially and federally.

Join our team
column10:
and help us win this.

column1:
AP Darrell Dunn Vermilion-Lloydminster-Wainwright

Meet Darrell:

I was initiated into prairie politics a long time ago when I was a kid and my Dad introduced me to the then Premier of Saskatchewan. Learning about ‘Citizenship’ was done around our kitchen table and the prevailing attitude was
column2:
“You need to be involved to get things done”.

It didn’t so much matter who the party was as it did to vote for the person best qualified to represent you.

My wife and I have lived in Lloydminster for 15 years now and it is home. I have worked throughout the constituency and know it well. My business is a legal issue consultancy including private investigations
column5: and Notary and Commissioning duties. Along with those activities
column6: I have been involved with the Snowflake House Respite Foundation
column7: the Lloydminster Concerned Citizens for Seniors Care Society
column8: and a run for City Council in 2020. In 2022 I became the Vice President of the Alberta Party and am currently Corporate Secretary. I’ve enjoyed various careers including agriculture
column12: consultant and advocate. My educational background includes law
column14:
history and economics.

I will bring strong
column16:
forward-thinking leadership to the role and am committed to being a positive and responsive MLA.It's time to walk the walk and I would be honoured to take the voices of Vermilion-Lloydminster-Wainwright to Edmonton!

column1:
AP Kevin Todd Livingstone-Macleod

Meet Kevin:

Kevin Todd was born and raised in the community of Nanton and has had the privilege of raising his own family in the same town.

As his family has grown in this rural community
column2: so has his commitment and service to the town and surrounding areas. Kevin has always been an active member of the community
column3: whether it be volunteering with the Nanton Futures Foundation
column5: or the Nanton Golf Club. He also holds previous municipal political experience
column6: having served on the Town Council for multiple years. Sharing his deep sense of neighbourhood involvement
column7:
Kevin's wife and both of his daughters are also an active part of the Nanton community.

Starting at the age of 12
column8: Kevin travelled throughout Southern Alberta as both a hockey player and referee. He continues to travel through the riding as an avid outdoorsman and spends many weekends with his family camping
column12:
beautiful backyard that is the Rocky Mountains.

Kevin’s background in finance and his keen entrepreneurial spirit are what keeps him visiting all parts of the province and beyond as part of his work life. He never misses an opportunity to learn something new from a stranger
column13: hop in his truck and drive a couple of hours for a cup of coffee
column14:
or have a chat about the importance of getting outdoors and getting back to nature.

As much as he enjoys collaborating with people from all walks of life and exploring the small-town gems Alberta has to offer
column15: Kevin always finds himself drawn back to Nanton. To him
column16: southern Alberta is the heart of the province
column17:
and it holds a special place for both himself and his family.

column1:
AP Myles Chykerda Lacombe-Ponoka

Meet Myles:

Myles Chykerda is a 4th generation rural Albertan born and raised in Stettler and Lacombe. He is part of a family with deep roots in farming
column3: and the oil and gas industry. Family and community are central aspects of what the Chykerda clan believes in
column4:
and Myles has a longhistory of community engagement and accepting leadership roles in non-profit societies.

But Myles has not lived solely in rural areas and has spent time in Athens
column5: Greece and LosAngeles. Living abroad allowed him to experience different cultures
column6: but has always increased his appreciation for what we have in Alberta. While attending University of Alberta
column7: he was an early adopter of downtown living
column8:
moving into a condo in the heart of Edmonton’s financial district in 2004.

While in Edmonton he met and became friends with numerous people that had been left behind by the boom. Individuals living on the street had been largely forgotten and left without anywhere to go for help or any aid to help them succeed. The idea of a hand-UP as opposed to a hand-out is something that strongly resonates with Myles.

Myles believes in a balanced society supported by an efficient government. The economy and ensuring Albertans have access to quality jobs is vital
column9: and health care and education are paramount
column10:
but non-profits and fine arts groups are equally important in the creation of a rich Alberta that can be enjoyed by all.

Myles is a professional archaeologist with Bachelor and Master of Arts degrees from UofA and a soon-to-be-completed Ph.D. from University of California Los Angeles (UCLA). He has worked on projects in Alberta
column13: and focuses on understanding how complex societies form through an interaction of natural landscapes
column15: and social memory. He also dabbles in museum exhibit design and had his work showcased early this year in the Diachonic Museum of Larissa
column16:
Greece.

Teaching is also a passion for Myles. While at UCLA
column17:
he instructed various courses ranging from Greek Archaeology to World Mythology. A core

component of all these classes was ensuring students learned to think critically and analyze the world around them. He also participated regularly in outreach activities that brought archaeological artifacts and a passion for history and the ancient world to inner-city schools.

All his experiences have led Myles to believe in governance via open and transparent processes rooted in facts and logic. As the former Alberta Party candidate for Lacombe-Ponoka
column18: he championed issues that matter to the area
column19: including pragmatic solutions to rural crime
column20: sustainable improvements to the region’s healthcare system
column21:
and building an efficient Government of Alberta that offers needed support to all Albertans.

Following the 2019 election
column22: Myles joined the Alberta Party's Provincial Board
column23:
where he serves as Corporate Secretary.

Given his passion for learning
column24:
Myles is also proud to serve as the Alberta Party's Shadow Minister for Advanced Education.

You can explore Myles' research interests at Academia.edu!
